title: 107_s1777
content: The Act is titled the "International Disability and Victims of Landmines, Civil Strife and Warfare Assistance Act of 2002". Congress finds that tens of millions of landmines in over 60 countries cause around 24,000 casualties annually, with only a small portion of US mine action funding directly aiding victims through programs like the Patrick Leahy War Victims Fund. The Patrick Leahy War Victims Fund provides prosthetics and rehabilitation for landmine and war victims in developing countries, improving quality of life by addressing accessibility, social stigmatization, and economic opportunities. Enhanced coordination among Federal agencies is needed for better assistance programs. Disabled individuals face lower education and income levels, with higher poverty rates according to the World Bank. The purpose of this Act is to authorize assistance for individuals with disabilities, including victims of landmines and other victims of civil strife and warfare. Numerous international human rights conventions recognize the need to protect the rights of individuals with disabilities through equality and non-discrimination principles. SEC. 135 of the Foreign Assistance Act of 1961 provides assistance for international disabilities and war victims. The President is authorized to provide assistance to individuals with disabilities, including victims of civil strife and warfare, in foreign countries. Programs may include developing local capacity for medical and rehabilitation services, training medical professionals, and supporting sustainable prosthetic services. Support for sustainable prosthetic and orthotic services, psychological and social rehabilitation of individuals with disabilities, policy reform, educational efforts, and coordination of programs for individuals with disabilities, including victims of civil strife and warfare in foreign countries. Support for establishing entities to coordinate programs and projects. Support for coordination of programs and activities related to assistance for individuals with disabilities, including victims of civil strife and warfare. Priority given to providing assistance through nongovernmental organizations and governments to establish norms and policies related to rehabilitation for individuals with disabilities. Funding authorized for programs assisting individuals with disabilities, including victims of civil strife and warfare, regardless of other laws. SEC. 4. RESEARCH, PREVENTION, AND ASSISTANCE RELATED TO INTERNATIONAL DISABILITIES AND LANDMINE AND OTHER WAR VICTIMS. The Secretary of Health and Human Services is authorized to conduct programs in foreign countries related to individuals with disabilities, including victims of landmines and civil strife. Grants can also be provided to nongovernmental organizations for research, prevention, and public awareness programs in foreign countries related to individuals with disabilities. Programs established for individuals with disabilities in foreign countries require coordination with the Administrator of the United States Agency for International Development and approval from the Secretary of State. Activities may include research on trauma, rehabilitation, and medical care, focusing on psychological and social factors for successful recovery. Interventions to reduce post-traumatic stress and promote well-being, including developing medical response tools and instruction manuals for patients and healthcare providers. Facilitation of peer support networks for individuals with disabilities in foreign countries, focusing on physical, psychological, economic, and social rehabilitation needs. The text chunk discusses the establishment of peer support networks for individuals with disabilities in foreign countries, focusing on social rehabilitation, economic reintegration, and training for outreach workers. Additionally, it mentions sharing expertise from research centers in the United States with similar centers in war-affected countries to promote health for individuals with limb loss and deficiency. The text chunk focuses on developing a database of best practices to address the needs of war-related disabled individuals through support activities and access to medical care. Authorization of appropriations is also mentioned for fiscal years 2003 through 2004. The Department of Veterans Affairs' expertise is highlighted in the text chunk. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs is authorized to provide advice and expertise on prosthetics, orthotics, rehabilitation, and disability assistance to other federal departments and agencies. This includes temporary assignment of VA personnel for programs assisting victims of landmines and civil strife in foreign countries, as well as providing technical assistance to private voluntary organizations. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs is authorized to provide advice and expertise on prosthetics, orthotics, rehabilitation, and disability assistance to other federal departments and agencies. This includes temporary assignment of VA personnel for programs assisting victims of landmines and civil strife in foreign countries, as well as providing technical assistance to private voluntary organizations on a reimbursable basis for landmine assistance, research, and prevention programs. The Senate passed S. 1777 on September 13, 2002, authorizing assistance for individuals with disabilities in foreign countries, including victims of landmines and civil strife.
